questions.description: Which proteins will be included in H-zone of myofilaments if sarcomere is in relaxed state?
questions.content_html:
A sarcomere is the basic unit of a muscle fiber. It is made up of two main protein filaments: actin (thin filaments) and myosin (thick filaments). The H-zone is the central region of the sarcomere where only myosin filaments are present.

In a relaxed state, the actin and myosin filaments do not overlap much, and the H-zone contains only myosin filaments.

During muscle contraction, the actin filaments slide over the myosin filaments, shortening the sarcomere and causing the muscle to contract. The H-zone decreases in size as the actin and myosin filaments overlap.

questions.description: Select the activity which would essentially involve movement but not result in locomotion?
questions.content_html:
Movement refers to any change in the position or location of an organism or part of an organism. There are different types of movement: * Locomotion involves a change in location, like walking or swimming. * Muscle Contraction is the shortening of muscle fibers, which is essential for both movement and locomotion. * Cellular Movement includes processes like amoeboid movement and ciliary movement, crucial for cell functions. * Internal Movement refers to movements within the body, like the movement of food through the digestive tract or blood through the circulatory system.

Now, imagine something that involves movement, but not locomotion. Think of how your tongue moves when you talk. It is definitely movement, but it doesn't cause you to change location.

questions.description: Locomotory structures in macrophages found in tissues, are:
questions.content_html: Macrophages are specialized cells in our body that exhibit amoeboid movement. This means they move by extending temporary projections called pseudopodia, which are formed by the streaming of their cytoplasm. Pseudopodia act like tiny feet, allowing macrophages to navigate through tissues and engulf foreign invaders like bacteria and viruses. Macrophages are essential for the immune system, as they play a crucial role in defending the body against infections and maintaining tissue health.

questions.description: 'I' am primarily involved in locomotory actions and changes of body postures. 'I' have striped muscle fibres when observed through the microscope and my activities are under the voluntary control of the nervous system. Who am 'I'?
questions.content_html:
I am a type of muscle that is primarily responsible for movement and posture changes. Under a microscope, I appear striped due to my unique muscle fibers. My actions are under the control of the nervous system, meaning I am voluntary. What am I?

Answer: Biceps

The answer is the biceps muscle because it:

  • Is involved in movement and posture: Biceps are key muscles for bending the arm, allowing for movement and holding postures.
  • Has striped muscle fibers: Skeletal muscle, like the biceps, appears striped due to the arrangement of its protein filaments.
  • Is under voluntary control: You consciously decide to move your arm, making the biceps a voluntary muscle.

questions.description: Cytoplasmic streaming, a characteristic of amoeba and white blood cells of vertebrates is caused by:
questions.content_html: Cytoplasmic streaming, the movement of cytoplasm within a cell, is a fascinating process that helps cells like amoeba and white blood cells of vertebrates move. This dynamic flow is powered by contracting microfilaments, which are thin, thread-like structures made of the protein actin. These microfilaments work like tiny muscles, pulling on the cytoplasm and causing it to move in a directed manner. Imagine these microfilaments as a network of tiny ropes, pulling and stretching the cytoplasm, creating a fluid-like motion. This streaming helps amoeba to change shape and move around, while white blood cells use it to squeeze through narrow spaces in the body to fight infection. So, the next time you think of movement, remember that even the smallest of cells have their own internal system of movement, powered by contracting microfilaments!

questions.description: Globular regulatory protein of skeletal muscle fibres is:
questions.content_html:
Skeletal muscle fibers are made up of protein filaments that slide past each other to cause contraction. These filaments are regulated by regulatory proteins, such as troponin. Troponin is a globular protein that binds to calcium ions, which triggers a conformational change in the fiber, allowing the filaments to slide. This process is essential for muscle movement.

Answer: Troponin.

questions.description: Property common to muscular and neural tissues is:
questions.content_html: Muscular and neural tissues are both excitable, meaning they can respond to stimuli. Muscles contract in response to signals from the nervous system. Nerve cells, on the other hand, conduct electrical impulses to trigger muscle contractions, allowing for movement and locomotion. Think of it like this: nerves are the messengers, and muscles are the movers! Both types of tissues rely on this property of excitability to work together.

questions.description: Dimensions of which of the following remains unaffected when skeletal muscle fibres are in maximally contracted state?
questions.content_html:
Skeletal muscles are made up of muscle fibers, which are long, cylindrical cells that contain many smaller units called sarcomeres. These sarcomeres are the functional units of muscle contraction.

Each sarcomere has a dark band called the Anisotropic band (A-band), which is composed of thick myosin filaments. The A-band remains unaffected during muscle contraction because it is made up of myosin filaments, which do not change in length during contraction. The I-bands, which are made up of thin actin filaments, shorten during contraction, but the A-bands do not.

questions.description: Red muscle fibres differ from white muscles fibres as:

options.description: Former contains large quantities of oxygen binding pigment haemoglobin
Latter has larger amount of sarcoplasmic reticulum than former
Former are unbranched and multinucleated while latter are not
Latter are responsible for aerobic respiration while former undergo only anaerobic respiration

questions.content_html:
Muscle fibers are the building blocks of muscles. There are two main types: red muscle and white muscle. Red muscle fibers are rich in myoglobin, a protein that stores oxygen, giving them their reddish color. They are also packed with mitochondria, which are the powerhouses of cells. This makes red muscle fibers ideal for sustained, aerobic activities like long-distance running. White muscle fibers, on the other hand, have less myoglobin and mitochondria. They rely on anaerobic metabolism for energy, which is less efficient but allows for short bursts of intense activity, like sprinting.

The sarcoplasmic reticulum is a network of membranes within muscle fibers that stores calcium ions. When a muscle contracts, calcium ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, triggering the interaction of actin and myosin filaments, which are the proteins responsible for muscle contraction. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is more developed in white muscle fibers than in red muscle fibers, which allows for faster calcium release and quicker muscle contraction.

questions.description: Sliding filament model of muscle contraction suggests that, the polymerised molecules that move to shorten a muscle are those of:
questions.content_html:
The sliding filament model describes how muscles contract. Imagine a muscle fiber as a tiny train track with two types of train cars: actin (thin) and myosin (thick).

During contraction, the actin cars slide along the myosin cars. This sliding shortens the distance between two points called Z lines, which mark the boundaries of a functional unit called a sarcomere. This shortening of the sarcomeres is what makes the muscle contract.

The key to this process is that the actin filaments are the ones that move. Myosin filaments remain stationary, while the actin filaments slide past them, creating a shortening effect.

questions.description: Ions essential for muscles contraction are stored in:
questions.content_html:
Muscle contraction is a complex process that involves the interaction of several components, including the sarcoplasmic reticulum, calcium ions, and myofilaments. The sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) is a specialized endoplasmic reticulum found in muscle cells. It functions as a calcium storage and release center, playing a crucial role in muscle contraction. When a signal for muscle contraction arrives, calcium ions are released from the SR, flooding the muscle cell's cytoplasm. These calcium ions bind to troponin, a protein associated with thin filaments, causing a conformational change that exposes binding sites on the actin filaments. The myosin heads, which are part of thick filaments, then bind to these exposed sites, forming cross-bridges. The interaction between actin and myosin, along with the energy provided by ATP hydrolysis, powers the sliding of thin filaments over thick filaments, resulting in muscle contraction. Once the signal for contraction ends, calcium ions are actively pumped back into the SR, leading to the detachment of myosin heads from actin, and the muscle relaxes.

This intricate interplay of calcium ions, the SR, and myofilaments is essential for muscle contraction and ultimately allows for locomotion and movement.

questions.description: The neurotransmitter usually released between a motor neuron and muscle cell is:
questions.content_html:
Motor neurons, which are specialized nerve cells, control muscle movement. They communicate with muscle cells at a specialized junction called the neuromuscular junction. At this junction, the motor neuron releases a chemical messenger called a neurotransmitter, specifically acetylcholine. Acetylcholine binds to receptors on the muscle cell, triggering a series of events that ultimately lead to muscle contraction.

The neurotransmitter usually released between a motor neuron and muscle cell is: Acetylcholine

questions.description: The regulatory protein of skeletal muscles whose filaments run close to the F-actin throughout its length is:
questions.content_html:
Skeletal muscles are responsible for voluntary movement in our bodies. They contain thin filaments made of a protein called actin and thick filaments made of another protein called myosin.

Tropomyosin is a regulatory protein that wraps around the actin filaments. It helps to control muscle contraction by blocking the myosin binding sites on actin when the muscle is at rest.

When a muscle receives a signal to contract, calcium ions bind to troponin, another regulatory protein. This causes tropomyosin to move out of the way, allowing myosin to bind to actin and initiate the sliding filament mechanism, resulting in muscle contraction.

questions.description: An active ATPase activity and binding site for ATP and actin filaments are found on:

options.description: Long tail of the meromyosin monomer

questions.content_html: Muscle contraction is a fascinating process powered by the interplay of proteins. Actin and myosin are the key players, with thin actin filaments sliding along thicker myosin filaments. The energy for this movement comes from ATP, which is broken down by ATPase, an enzyme found on the globular head of myosin. This head also has binding sites for both ATP and actin, allowing it to attach to actin filaments and pull them, creating the contraction. Heavy meromyosin (HMM), a part of the myosin molecule, includes the globular head with its ATPase activity and actin binding site, making it crucial for muscle contraction.

questions.description: Visceral muscles are also known as:
questions.content_html:
The muscles in your body can be classified into three types: skeletal muscles, visceral muscles, and cardiac muscles. Skeletal muscles are attached to bones and help you move voluntarily. Visceral muscles are found in the walls of internal organs like your stomach and intestines and are responsible for involuntary actions like digestion. Cardiac muscles are found only in the heart and are responsible for the rhythmic beating of your heart.

Visceral muscles are also known as involuntary non-striated muscles. They are involuntary, meaning that they are not under conscious control. They are also non-striated, meaning that they do not have the striped appearance of skeletal muscles.

questions.description: The central part of thick filament, not overlapped by thin filaments when a muscle is in relaxed state is called:
questions.content_html: The muscle structure is made up of repeating units called sarcomeres. Each sarcomere contains thick filaments (myosin) and thin filaments (actin). In the relaxed state, the thick and thin filaments partially overlap, with a gap in the middle of the thick filament called the H-zone. This H-zone is the central part of the thick filament that is not overlapped by the thin filaments. When the muscle contracts, the thin filaments slide over the thick filaments, causing the H-zone to disappear.

questions.description: The portion of the myofibril between two successive 'Z' lines is called:
questions.content_html:
The smallest functional unit of a muscle fiber is called a sarcomere. It's the section between two Z lines, which are protein structures that anchor the thin filaments (made of actin) and help with muscle contraction.

The myofibril is a long, cylindrical structure found within muscle fibers. It's made up of repeating sarcomeres, giving muscle fibers their striated appearance.

During muscle contraction, myosin (a thick filament) interacts with actin. Myosin heads bind to actin, forming cross-bridges. These cross-bridges pull the actin filaments toward the center of the sarcomere, causing the sarcomere to shorten. This shortening is what generates muscle force.

questions.description: Which of the following statement is not true regarding A-band?

options.description: Length remains constant during the muscle contraction

questions.content_html:
A sarcomere is the functional unit of a muscle fiber, responsible for muscle contraction. Each sarcomere contains thick filaments composed of the protein myosin and thin filaments composed of the protein actin. The A-band is the dark band in the sarcomere and contains the entire length of the thick filaments.

The thick filaments overlap with the thin filaments in the A-band, creating the zone of overlap. However, the A-band also contains a central region known as the H-zone, where only the thick filaments are present. The thin filaments are attached to the Z-line, which marks the boundary between adjacent sarcomeres.

During muscle contraction, the thin filaments slide past the thick filaments, pulling the Z-lines closer together. This shortening of the sarcomere results in the contraction of the entire muscle fiber.

The A-band does not contain only thick filaments as it also contains a region of overlap where thick and thin filaments interact. Therefore, the statement "Has thick filaments only" is not true regarding the A-band.

questions.description: Identify the trimeric protein which masks the active sites for myosin on acting filaments:
questions.content_html:
Muscle contraction is a fascinating process that allows us to move. It involves the interplay of several proteins, including actin, myosin, troponin, and tropomyosin.

Actin, a thin filament, forms the backbone of the muscle fiber, while myosin, a thick filament, interacts with actin to generate movement. Tropomyosin, a long protein, wraps around the actin filament, blocking the myosin binding sites.

Troponin, a trimeric protein, is crucial for regulating muscle contraction. It binds to tropomyosin and calcium. When calcium binds to troponin, it causes a conformational change in tropomyosin, exposing the myosin binding sites on actin, allowing the myosin to bind and initiate contraction.

questions.description: In a striated muscle fibre, Ca²⁺ is stored in:
questions.content_html: Striated muscle fibers, like those found in your biceps, are packed with tiny structures called myofibrils. These myofibrils are made up of even tinier filaments called actin and myosin. For a muscle to contract, calcium ions (Ca²⁺) need to be released. These calcium ions are stored in a network of membranous sacs within the muscle fiber called the sarcoplasmic reticulum. These sacs are actually specialized enlargements of the sarcoplasmic reticulum called cisternae. When a signal arrives from the nervous system to contract, the cisternae release their stored calcium. The calcium then interacts with the actin and myosin filaments, allowing them to slide past each other and shorten the muscle fiber, leading to a contraction.

questions.description: Which of the following is not applicable to red muscle fibres when compared to white muscle fibres?
questions.content_html:
Muscle fibers are the building blocks of muscles, responsible for movement. There are two main types:

  • Red muscle fibers: These fibers are rich in myoglobin, giving them a reddish color. They are specialized for endurance activities, using oxygen for energy. They contract slowly but can sustain contractions for longer periods.
  • White muscle fibers: These fibers have lower myoglobin content, making them appear white. They are adapted for short bursts of intense activity, relying primarily on anaerobic metabolism. They contract quickly but fatigue faster.

The major difference between red and white muscle fibers is the contraction rate. Red muscle fibers contract more slowly than white muscle fibers. This difference is due to their distinct energy production pathways and the type of myosin they contain.

Locomotion and movement rely on the coordinated action of different muscle fibers. Red and white muscle fibers work together to enable a wide range of movements, from sustained walking to explosive sprints.

Thick filaments slide inward towards the M-line

questions.description: Which of the following muscles are not under the voluntary control of nervous system?
questions.content_html:
Our bodies are made up of different types of muscles. Some muscles are under our conscious control, like the muscles that move our arms and legs. These are called voluntary muscles. Others work without us thinking about them, like the muscles that help our heart beat or the muscles that move food through our digestive system. These are called involuntary muscles.

Involuntary muscles are also known as smooth muscles. They are found in the walls of organs like the stomach, intestines, and the urinary bladder. The nervous system does not directly control these muscles, meaning we can't consciously make them contract or relax.

questions.content_html:
Muscle contraction is the process that allows our bodies to move. It happens at the microscopic level within structures called sarcomeres.

The sarcomere is the basic unit of muscle contraction and is made up of two main protein filaments: actin (thin) and myosin (thick). The M line is a protein structure located in the center of the sarcomere, anchoring the thick myosin filaments.

When a muscle contracts, the actin and myosin filaments slide past each other, shortening the sarcomere. This sliding motion is powered by the interaction of myosin heads with actin filaments. As the muscle contracts, the M line disappears.

questions.description: Which one of the following ions is essential for muscular contraction?
questions.content_html:
Muscle contraction is a fascinating process that allows us to move. It involves the interaction of two proteins: actin and myosin. Actin is a thin filament, while myosin is a thick filament. These filaments slide past each other, shortening the muscle fiber.

But how does this sliding happen? The key player is calcium (Ca⁺⁺). When a nerve impulse reaches a muscle fiber, it triggers the release of calcium ions from storage. These ions bind to a protein called troponin, which is attached to actin. This binding causes a change in the shape of troponin, exposing the active sites on actin for myosin to bind.

Myosin then binds to actin, forming a cross-bridge. The myosin head then pulls on the actin filament, causing it to slide past the myosin. This process requires energy, which is provided by ATP.

Once the calcium ions are removed, troponin returns to its original shape, blocking the active sites on actin. Myosin detaches, and the muscle relaxes.

Therefore, calcium ions are essential for muscle contraction. Without calcium, the myosin cannot bind to actin, and the muscle cannot contract.

questions.content_html:
A muscle twitch is a quick, involuntary contraction of a muscle fiber caused by a single action potential. This action potential triggers the release of calcium ions, which bind to the actin filaments, allowing the myosin filaments to attach and pull, resulting in a contraction.

The muscle then relaxes as the calcium ions are pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, causing the myosin to detach from the actin. This entire process of contraction and relaxation constitutes a muscle twitch.

This is a fundamental concept in muscle physiology, which studies the function and properties of muscles. Understanding muscle twitches is crucial for understanding how muscles contract and relax in response to nerve stimulation.

questions.description: Which type of joint is seen between carpals?
questions.content_html:
Joints are the connections between bones, allowing for movement. There are different types of joints, each with unique characteristics:

  • Fibrous joints: Immovable, connected by fibrous tissue, like the skull bones.
  • Cartilaginous joints: Slightly movable, connected by cartilage, like the vertebrae.
  • Synovial joints: Freely movable, filled with synovial fluid and enclosed by a capsule, like the knee and hip joints.

One type of synovial joint is a gliding joint, which allows bones to slide past each other. The carpals, small bones in the wrist, form gliding joints with each other. This allows for the complex movements of the hand.

questions.content_html:
The human rib cage is made up of 12 pairs of ribs that are connected to the vertebral column (backbone). The first seven pairs of ribs are called true ribs because they are directly connected to the sternum (breastbone) by cartilage. The next three pairs are called false ribs because they are connected to the sternum through cartilage. The final two pairs of ribs are called floating ribs because they are not attached to the sternum at all.

Vertebrochondral ribs refer to the 8th, 9th, and 10th pairs of ribs. These ribs are connected to the sternum via cartilage, making them false ribs. They are not directly connected to the sternum like true ribs.

The statement "Vertebrochondral ribs - 11th and 12th pair of ribs" is incorrect. The 11th and 12th pairs of ribs are the floating ribs, which are not connected to the sternum at all.

questions.description: Knee joint and elbow joint are examples of:
questions.content_html:
Joints: The Movers and Shakers

Our bodies are incredibly complex machines, and joints are the crucial components that enable movement. There are different types of joints, each allowing for varying degrees of motion.

Synovial joints are the most common type, allowing for a wide range of movement. They are characterized by a fluid-filled cavity that lubricates the joint and reduces friction. These joints are further classified based on their movement capabilities.

Hinge joints are one such type, allowing movement in only one plane, like a door hinge. The knee joint and elbow joint are prime examples of hinge joints, allowing you to bend and straighten your limbs.

Movement and locomotion work together to allow us to move about. Locomotion refers to the act of moving from one place to another, while movement encompasses all types of motion, including subtle changes in posture.

questions.description: Which of the following is not an auto immune disorder?
questions.content_html:
Autoimmune disorders occur when the immune system attacks the body's own tissues. Common examples include rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, and multiple sclerosis.

Inflammation is a natural process that helps the body heal after injury or infection. However, chronic inflammation can contribute to many diseases, including autoimmune disorders.

Gout is a condition caused by the buildup of uric acid in the joints, leading to painful inflammation and swelling. It is not an autoimmune disorder because the immune system is not involved in its development.

Locomotion and movement are essential for everyday activities. They rely on the coordinated action of muscles, bones, and joints.

The answer is Simple gout.

questions.description: Progressive degeneration of skeletal muscle mostly due to genetic disorder is:
questions.content_html: Muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder that causes progressive degeneration of skeletal muscle, primarily affecting the muscles responsible for movement. This degeneration weakens the muscles, making it progressively harder to move and walk, and ultimately affecting locomotion and movement. As the condition worsens, it can lead to difficulty with basic activities like breathing and swallowing. There are several types of muscular dystrophy, each with different severity and rate of progression. Although there is no cure for muscular dystrophy, treatments aim to slow its progression and manage symptoms to improve quality of life.

questions.description: Decreased level of estrogen in the females after menopause is implicated as a common causative factor of:
questions.content_html: Estrogen is a hormone that plays a crucial role in maintaining bone density. After menopause, a woman's estrogen levels decline, which can lead to a decrease in bone density, making her more susceptible to osteoporosis. Osteoporosis weakens bones, increasing the risk of fractures. To combat this, women are encouraged to consume a calcium-rich diet and engage in regular weight-bearing exercises. These actions can help strengthen bones and prevent osteoporosis.

questions.description: Which of the following muscle disorder occurs due to formation of defective antibodies?
questions.content_html: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that affects the neuromuscular junction, the point where nerve signals meet muscles. In this condition, the body produces antibodies that attack the acetylcholine receptors on muscle cells, leading to muscle weakness. These antibodies interfere with the ability of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter, to bind to its receptors, disrupting the normal communication between nerves and muscles. This disruption results in a decrease in muscle activation, causing fatigue and weakness. The condition is most commonly seen in the muscles responsible for eye movement, facial expressions, swallowing, and limb movement.

  • Fibrous Joints: These joints are immovable and are held together by strong connective tissues. They are found in the skull, where they help protect the brain.
  • Cartilaginous Joints: These joints allow for limited movement and are connected by cartilage. They are found in the vertebral column, allowing for flexibility but also providing support.
  • Synovial Joints: These joints are freely movable and are the most common type of joint in the body. They have a fluid-filled cavity that allows for smooth movement. They are found in the limbs, allowing for a wide range of motions.

questions.content_html:
The skeletal system is made up of bones and cartilage, providing support and structure for movement. Bones contain calcium and are hard, while cartilage is flexible. The skeletal system is divided into two main parts: the axial skeleton (skull, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum) and the appendicular skeleton (limb bones and their girdles).

Osteoporosis is a condition that weakens bones, making them more prone to fractures. This occurs due to a decrease in bone mass, often associated with aging.

Movement involves muscles, which contract and relax to move bones. There are three types of muscle: skeletal (attached to bones, voluntary), smooth (found in organs, involuntary), and cardiac (found in the heart, involuntary).

Locomotion is a specific type of movement that involves a change in location. It is achieved through coordinated muscle action and skeletal support.

Therefore, the correct match is Osteoporosis - Decrease in bone mass and higher chances of fractures with advancing age.

questions.description: Which of the following component is a part of the pectoral girdle?
questions.content_html: The pectoral girdle is the bony structure that connects the upper limbs to the axial skeleton. It is made up of two bones: the clavicle (collarbone) and the scapula (shoulder blade). The glenoid cavity is a shallow socket on the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus (upper arm bone) to form the shoulder joint. The shoulder joint is a ball-and-socket joint, allowing for a wide range of motion. The glenoid cavity is a part of the pectoral girdle because it is located on the scapula, which is one of the two bones that make up the pectoral girdle.

questions.description: The joint between carpal and metacarpal of thumb in man is:
questions.content_html:
The human thumb is unique because it has a joint called the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. This joint allows for a wide range of movement, and its shape is called a saddle joint. Saddle joints are found in the thumb because they allow for movement in two planes, back and forth and side to side. A saddle joint is a type of synovial joint, which means that it is filled with fluid to lubricate and cushion the joint. This type of joint allows for a wide range of movement, which is why the thumb is so flexible and useful.

The joint between carpal and metacarpal of thumb in man is: Saddle.

questions.description: Progressive degeneration of skeletal muscles due to genetic disorder is:
questions.content_html:
Muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder that causes progressive degeneration of skeletal muscles. Skeletal muscles are responsible for movement and locomotion, so their weakening can significantly impact a person's ability to move and walk.

The condition is caused by mutations in genes that are responsible for producing proteins that help maintain the structure and function of skeletal muscles. These mutations lead to the production of faulty proteins, which weakens the muscle fibers and causes them to break down over time.

As the disease progresses, individuals with muscular dystrophy may experience difficulty walking, climbing stairs, and performing other daily activities. The severity of the condition varies depending on the specific type of muscular dystrophy and the genes involved. There is currently no cure for muscular dystrophy, but there are treatments available to help manage symptoms and slow the progression of the disease.

questions.description: Select the odd one w.r.t. girdle bones:
Which of the following ribs are not connected ventrally with the sternum and are called as floating ribs?
questions.content_html: Your ribs are bones that form a cage around your chest, protecting your heart and lungs. There are 12 pairs of ribs in total. The first 7 pairs are called true ribs because they connect directly to your sternum (breastbone) via costal cartilage. The 8th, 9th, and 10th pairs are called false ribs because they connect to the sternum indirectly, through the cartilage of the 7th rib. The last 2 pairs (11th and 12th) are called floating ribs. They don't connect to the sternum at all. Instead, they are only attached to the vertebral column at their back, and are free at their ventral (front) ends.

questions.description: Which of the following are the regulatory proteins in the muscle contraction?
questions.content_html:
Muscle contraction is a complex process that requires the coordinated interaction of several proteins. The key players include actin and myosin, which form the thin and thick filaments, respectively. These filaments slide past each other, shortening the muscle fiber.

However, the process is regulated by two important proteins: troponin and tropomyosin. Tropomyosin wraps around the actin filament, blocking the binding sites for myosin. When calcium ions are released, they bind to troponin, causing it to change shape and move tropomyosin away from the binding sites. This allows myosin to bind to actin, initiating the sliding filament process and muscle contraction.

So, the answer to the question is that troponin and tropomyosin are the regulatory proteins involved in muscle contraction.

questions.description: During muscle contraction which of the following does not occur?

options.description: No change in length of anisotropic band
Decrease in length of isotropic band
No change in length of A band
Decrease in length of action myofilaments

questions.content_html:
Muscle contraction is a complex process that involves the interaction of two main proteins: actin and myosin. Actin is a thin filament, while myosin is a thick filament. These filaments are arranged in repeating units called sarcomeres, which are the basic functional units of muscle.

The sliding filament theory explains how muscle contraction occurs. When a muscle receives a signal to contract, the myosin heads bind to actin, forming a cross-bridge. The myosin heads then pull the actin filaments towards the center of the sarcomere, causing the sarcomere to shorten. This shortening is what we perceive as muscle contraction.

During muscle contraction, the length of the actin myofilaments does not change. Instead, the actin filaments slide past the myosin filaments, causing the sarcomere to shorten.

questions.description: What would happen if ATP suddenly were not available after the sarcomere had started to shorten?

options.description: Cross bridges would not be able to detach from actin
Muscle would remain in a state of rigidity

questions.content_html:
ATP, Sarcomere, Muscle Contraction, Sliding Filament Theory, Muscle Relaxation

Muscle contraction is a complex process that requires ATP, the energy currency of the cell. ATP is used to power the movement of the myosin heads along the actin filaments, causing the sarcomere to shorten. This process is known as the sliding filament theory.

Sarcomere: The sarcomere is the basic unit of muscle contraction. It is composed of thick myosin filaments and thin actin filaments.

Muscle Contraction: When a muscle contracts, the myosin heads bind to the actin filaments and pull them towards the center of the sarcomere, causing the sarcomere to shorten.

Sliding Filament Theory: This theory explains how the myosin and actin filaments slide past each other to produce muscle contraction.

Muscle Relaxation: When ATP is no longer available, the myosin heads detach from the actin filaments and the sarcomere returns to its resting length.

What would happen if ATP suddenly were not available after the sarcomere had started to shorten?

If ATP were not available, the myosin heads would remain attached to the actin filaments, preventing the sarcomere from relaxing. This would result in muscle stiffness or rigor mortis.

questions.description: Myasthenia gravis involves weakness of skeletal muscles. Which of the following can act as a primary treatment of it?
questions.content_html:
Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that weakens skeletal muscles by interfering with the transmission of nerve signals at the neuromuscular junction. This junction is where a motor neuron releases acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter, to stimulate muscle contraction.

In myasthenia gravis, the body produces antibodies that attack acetylcholine receptors on muscle cells. This reduces the amount of acetylcholine that can bind to the receptors, causing muscle weakness.

One primary treatment for myasthenia gravis involves inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase. Acetylcholinesterase is an enzyme that normally breaks down acetylcholine after it has been released from the motor neuron. By blocking acetylcholinesterase, drugs can increase the amount of acetylcholine available at the neuromuscular junction, improving muscle function.

The ball is the head of the humerus (upper arm bone), and the socket is the glenoid cavity of the scapula.

questions.description: Bone formed by the ossification of tendon is called:
questions.content_html:
Our bodies are incredible machines, capable of amazing movements! One of the key components that allows us to move is our skeletal system, which is made up of bones. But how do bones form in the first place?

Bone Formation: This process, called ossification, starts with a framework of cartilage that is gradually replaced by hard bone tissue.

Tendon: A tough, fibrous cord of connective tissue that attaches muscle to bone. Tendons are essential for transmitting the force generated by muscles to move our bones.

Sesamoid Bone: These are small, round bones that form within tendons, where the tendon passes over a joint. Sesamoid bones act as pulleys, helping to improve the efficiency of the tendon and protect it from wear and tear. A great example is the kneecap, also called the patella, which is formed within the tendon of the quadriceps muscle.

Locomotion: This refers to the act of moving from one place to another. Locomotion requires the coordinated effort of our muscles, bones, and joints. We use different methods of locomotion, such as walking, running, swimming, and flying, depending on our environment and needs.

questions.description: If a muscle fibre contracts, which of the following will not occur?
questions.content_html:
Muscle contraction is driven by the sliding filament theory. It involves the interaction of actin and myosin filaments within a sarcomere, the basic unit of a muscle fiber.

  • Actin filaments: Thin filaments composed of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.
  • Myosin filaments: Thick filaments composed of myosin protein.

When a muscle fiber receives a signal to contract, calcium ions are released, triggering a series of events:

  1. Cross-bridge formation: Myosin heads bind to active sites on actin.
  2. Power stroke: Myosin heads pull actin filaments toward the center of the sarcomere.
  3. Cross-bridge detachment: Myosin heads detach from actin and reattach to new active sites.

The sliding of actin filaments past myosin filaments shortens the sarcomere, resulting in muscle contraction. Importantly, the length of actin filaments does not increase during this process.

questions.content_html:
The clavicle, or collarbone, is an S-shaped bone that connects the shoulder blade (scapula) to the breastbone (sternum). It has two distinct curves. The inner curve connects to the sternum, forming the sternoclavicular joint. The outer curve connects to the scapula, forming the acromioclavicular joint.

The clavicle is classified as a dermal bone, which means it develops from the skin's outer layer. It plays a crucial role in stabilizing the shoulder joint and allowing for a wide range of arm movements.

questions.content_html:
Locomotion is the movement of an organism from one place to another. This movement is made possible by the interaction of the muscular and skeletal systems. Muscles are the contractile tissues that provide the force for movement, while the skeletal system provides the framework and structure for the body.

The skeletal system is made up of bones and cartilage. Bones provide support, protection, and leverage for movement. They also store minerals and produce blood cells. Cartilage is a flexible connective tissue that cushions joints and reduces friction.

There are three types of muscle tissue: skeletal, smooth, and cardiac. Skeletal muscles are attached to bones and are responsible for voluntary movements like walking, running, and lifting. Smooth muscles are found in the walls of internal organs like the stomach and intestines and are responsible for involuntary movements like digestion and blood flow. Cardiac muscle is found only in the heart and is responsible for the rhythmic contractions that pump blood throughout the body.

The interaction of the muscular and skeletal systems allows for a wide range of movements, from simple actions like blinking to complex movements like running and dancing. The coordinated activity of muscles and bones is essential for locomotion and many other bodily functions.

Therefore, all of the following statements are true:

  • Locomotion is a type of movement.
  • Movement requires the interaction of muscles and the skeletal system.
  • Muscles are biological tissues responsible for movement.
  • The skeletal system provides support and structure for the body.

questions.description: Which one is not the character of red skeletal muscle fibres?
questions.content_html:
Skeletal muscles are made of muscle fibers, which are long, cylindrical cells that are responsible for movement. There are two main types of skeletal muscle fibers: red and white. Red muscle fibers are also known as slow-twitch fibers. They are rich in myoglobin, a protein that stores oxygen, giving them their reddish color. They have a high density of mitochondria, which are the powerhouses of the cell, and a lot of blood vessels. This means they are able to produce ATP, the energy currency of the cell, efficiently, even when oxygen is limited. Red fibers are specialized for endurance activities like running or swimming. White muscle fibers are also known as fast-twitch fibers. They have less myoglobin, mitochondria, and blood vessels. As a result, they are less efficient at producing ATP, but they can contract quickly and powerfully, making them ideal for short bursts of activity like sprinting or lifting weights.

The sarcoplasmic reticulum is a network of tubules and sacs that surrounds each muscle fiber. It stores calcium ions, which are essential for muscle contraction. When a muscle fiber is stimulated, calcium ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which causes the muscle fibers to contract. Red muscle fibers have less sarcoplasmic reticulum than white muscle fibers.

In general, red muscle fibers are characterized by:

  • Higher myoglobin content
  • Greater density of mitochondria
  • More blood vessels
  • Greater resistance to fatigue
  • Slower contraction speed
  • Lower power output

While white muscle fibers are characterized by:

  • Lower myoglobin content
  • Lower density of mitochondria
  • Fewer blood vessels
  • Lower resistance to fatigue
  • Faster contraction speed
  • Higher power output

questions.description: Least blood supply will be present in case of:
questions.content_html:
Muscle tissue is a specialized tissue that allows for movement. There are three types of muscle tissue: skeletal, smooth, and cardiac. Skeletal muscles are attached to bones and are responsible for voluntary movements. Smooth muscle is found in the walls of internal organs, such as the digestive system and blood vessels, and is responsible for involuntary movements. Cardiac muscle is found only in the heart and is responsible for pumping blood.

Of the three types, smooth muscle has the least blood supply. This is because smooth muscle contracts slowly and does not require as much oxygen as skeletal muscle, which contracts quickly and forcefully. The body prioritizes blood flow to areas that require the most oxygen, so smooth muscle receives a lower blood supply.

The other key terms in this list are also important to understand movement:

  • Blood supply: The delivery of oxygenated blood to tissues, vital for muscle function.
  • Oxygenation: The process of supplying oxygen to the blood and tissues, crucial for muscle contraction.
  • Locomotion: The movement of an organism from one place to another.

questions.description: Number of anterior curves present with human vertebral column is:
questions.content_html:
The vertebral column, also known as the spine, is a flexible, segmented rod that supports the human body and helps with locomotion. It has four natural curves: two anterior curves (cervical and lumbar) and two posterior curves (thoracic and sacral). These curves provide the spine with flexibility and shock absorption. The anterior curves are important for maintaining an upright posture and for allowing the spine to bend forward.

Number of anterior curves present with human vertebral column is: 2

questions.description: Phalangeal formula for the hand of a human is:
questions.content_html:
The phalangeal formula is a shorthand way to describe the number of bones in each digit of the hand. It's represented as a series of numbers, with each number corresponding to a digit: thumb, index finger, middle finger, ring finger, and pinky.

The phalangeal formula for a human hand is 23333. This means:

  • Thumb: 2 bones (proximal and distal)
  • Index, Middle, Ring, and Pinky: 3 bones each (proximal, middle, and distal)

questions.description: What is the type of movable joint present between the atlas and axis?
questions.content_html: Joints are connections between bones that allow for movement. There are different types of joints, including pivot joints. Pivot joints allow for rotational movement. An example is the joint between the atlas (first cervical vertebra) and axis (second cervical vertebra). This joint allows for the head to rotate from side to side, like shaking your head "no". The atlas is a ring-shaped bone that supports the skull, while the axis has a bony projection called the odontoid process that fits into the ring of the atlas, allowing for rotation.

questions.description: ATPase of the muscle is located in:
questions.content_html:
Muscle contraction is powered by a fascinating interplay of proteins. The sarcomere, the basic unit of muscle, contains thin filaments of actin and thick filaments of myosin. When a muscle receives a signal to contract, the myosin heads, which contain the enzyme ATPase, use energy from ATP to bind to actin. This binding causes the myosin to pull the actin filaments, shortening the sarcomere and causing muscle contraction.

The ATPase of the muscle is located in myosin, which is responsible for breaking down ATP to provide the energy needed for muscle contraction.

questions.description: Which one of the following is showing the correct sequential order of vertebrae in the vertebral column of human beings?
questions.content_html:
The vertebral column, also known as the spine, is made up of 33 individual bones called vertebrae. They are stacked on top of each other to form a flexible and strong structure that supports the body. The vertebrae are divided into five regions:

  • Cervical vertebrae (7) are located in the neck.
  • Thoracic vertebrae (12) are located in the chest.
  • Lumbar vertebrae (5) are located in the lower back.
  • Sacral vertebrae (5) are fused together to form the sacrum.
  • Coccygeal vertebrae (4) are fused together to form the coccyx (tailbone).

The correct sequential order of these vertebrae is: Cervical–thoracic–lumbar–sacral–coccygeal. This order helps us understand how the spine is structured and how the different regions contribute to its overall function.

questions.description: Knee joint and elbow joint are examples of:
questions.content_html:
Our bodies are made up of many joints that allow us to move. There are different types of joints, with synovial joints being the most common. Synovial joints are characterized by a fluid-filled cavity that allows for a wide range of motion.

One type of synovial joint is the hinge joint, which allows movement in one direction, like a door hinge. The knee joint and elbow joint are prime examples of hinge joints. The knee allows us to bend and straighten our leg, while the elbow allows us to bend and straighten our arm.

questions.description: Macrophages and leucocytes exhibit:
questions.content_html: Macrophages and leucocytes are types of white blood cells that play a crucial role in our immune system. They are able to move around in the body using amoeboid movement, a type of cell movement that relies on the extension and retraction of cytoplasm. This allows them to reach areas where they are needed, like sites of infection, to fight off pathogens. One of their primary functions is phagocytosis, where they engulf and destroy harmful substances like bacteria and cellular debris.

This movement is crucial for these cells as they are involved in immune responses, where they need to reach the site of infection or inflammation to engulf and destroy pathogens. This process of engulfing and digesting foreign particles is called phagocytosis.

questions.content_html:
Our bodies have three main types of muscle: skeletal, smooth, and cardiac. Skeletal muscles are attached to bones and help us move. They are striated (have stripes) and are under voluntary control, meaning we can consciously control them. Smooth muscle lines the walls of internal organs like the alimentary canal (digestive tract), blood vessels, and bladder. This muscle is not striated and works involuntarily, meaning we don't consciously control it. It helps with digestion, blood pressure regulation, and other essential functions. Cardiac muscle is found only in the heart and is responsible for its rhythmic contractions. It is striated and involuntary, controlled by its own internal pacemaker.

The statement that muscles located in the inner walls of the alimentary canal are striated and involuntary is incorrect because while smooth muscle in the alimentary canal is involuntary, it is not striated.

  • Smooth muscles are found in the walls of internal organs like the digestive tract and blood vessels. They are involuntary, meaning they contract without conscious control. They have a smooth appearance under a microscope.

The muscles of the heart, also known as cardiac muscles, have a characteristic striation and are involuntary in nature. They are responsible for the rhythmic contraction and relaxation of the heart, which pumps blood throughout the body.

questions.description: Which pair of ribs do not articulate directly with the sternum but attach with hyaline cartilage of other rib?
questions.content_html:
The rib cage is an essential part of the human skeletal system, protecting vital organs and supporting the respiratory system. It is comprised of 12 pairs of ribs, which attach to the vertebral column at the back.

The first 7 pairs are known as true ribs, directly articulating with the sternum via hyaline cartilage. The remaining 5 pairs are false ribs. The 8th, 9th, and 10th pairs connect to the sternum indirectly, attaching to the hyaline cartilage of the 7th rib. The last 2 pairs, known as floating ribs, do not attach to the sternum at all.

These ribs, along with the sternum, form the protective rib cage that encases the heart, lungs, and other vital organs. The hyaline cartilage at the ends of ribs allows for smooth, flexible movement during breathing.
